question.title: How do you print an emoji in VSCode?
question.body:
(UTF_8, though I did try UTF_16. Places where I was using UTF_16 are marked) I'm trying to print a red heart and have so far come up completely blank, here are some of my attempts:

Attempt 1:

String input = "❤️"; // A red heart, what I'm HOPING will print into the terminal

System.out.println("output: " + input); // the "straight up copy and paste" method

Result:

output: ??

Attempt 2:

String input = "❤️"; // A red heart, what I'm HOPING will print into the terminal
int codePoint = input.codePointAt(0) ; // converts the red heart to a Decimal Code Point
System.out.println("codePoint: " + codePoint); // prints the code point to ensure its printing the right thing
String output2 = Character.toString(codePoint); // converts the code point to a red heart

System.out.println("output2: " + output2); // the "convert the codepoint to a string direct" method

Result:

codePoint: 10084
output2: ?

Attempt 3:

String output3 = Character.toString(10084);

System.out.println("output3: " + output3); // the "convert the codepoint to a string indirect" method

Result:

output3: ?

Attempt 4:

System.out.println("output4: " + "\u2764\uFE0F"); // the "unicode" method

Result:

output4: ??

Attempt 5:

PrintWriter printWriter = new PrintWriter(System.out,true);
char output5p1 = '\u2764';
char output5p2 = '\uFE0F';
printWriter.println("output5: " + output5p1 + output5p2); // the "printWriter + char" method

Result:

output5: ??

I tried typing chcp 65001 into the terminal (got the idea to do this from this post) and got a different result, but still not a necessarily favorable one.

codePoint: 10084
output: Γ¥ñ∩╕Å
output2: Γ¥ñ
output3: Γ¥ñ
output4: Γ¥ñ∩╕Å
output5: Γ¥ñ∩╕Å

Results using UTF-16 LE:

codePoint: 10084
output: Γ¥ñ∩╕Å
output2: Γ¥ñ
output3: Γ¥ñ
output4: Γ¥ñ∩╕Å
output5: Γ¥ñ∩╕Å

The problem is, I've found that OTHER unicode characters work just fine:

System.out.println("output: " + "\u00FF"); // the last char on the Latin 1 Supplement char set
System.out.println("output2: " + "\u0100"); // the first char on the extended Latin 1 char set

Result:

output: ÿ
output2: ?

The first character prints as expected, whereas the second prints as a question mark.

I know that this question has been asked before, but as I've shown above, I have done my due diligence in trying to find a solution on my own and have come up completely blank. From what I've seen, my first attempt should've been enough.

I had originally tried to do this on Replit, but had to move to VSCode since my program got too big. It originally printed a red heart with no issue.

Update:

My question got closed as a duplicate, so I checked the post that was linked to see if I could get any new info, and I also tried something another user commented (Thank you, DuncG!) The solution in the other post was that the were not using UTF-8, I know with 100% certainty, however, that I am.

Just as an extra precaution, however, I tried what DuncG suggested, which was to go into chcp 65001 mode and paste a heart into the terminal.

I've also tried changing the font to Segoe UI Emoji, since that is Windows' Emoji Font. This, however, was also unsuccessful:

I also tried using the Last Resort font:

That output in plain text (just a straight copy-paste from the terminal lol):

codePoint: 10084
codePoint: 65
output2: ?
Latin A: A

Ditto, but in chcp 65001 mode: 

codePoint: 10084
codePoint: 65
output2: Γ¥ñ
Latin A: A

I've tried both fonts with all versions of my code and still have yet to make a red heart. :(
